frames.core

Class Interpolator

  • java.lang.Object
    • frames.core.Interpolator

  • public class Interpolator
extends java.lang.Object
    A key frame Catmull-Rom interpolator.

    An interpolator holds key frames (that define a path) and, optionally, a reference to a frame of your application (which will be interpolated). In this case, when the user start(), the interpolator regularly updates the frame() position, orientation and magnitude along the path.

    Here is a typical usage example: 

     
 void init() {
   Graph graph = new Graph(1200, 800);
   Interpolator interpolator = new Interpolator(graph);
   for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++)
     interpolator.addKeyFrame(Frame.random(graph));
   interpolator.start();
 }
    which will create a random (see Frame.random(Graph)) interpolator path containing 10 key-frames (see addKeyFrame(Frame)). The interpolation is also started (see start()).

    The graph main drawing loop should look like: 

     
 void mainLoop() {
   graph.pushModelView();
   graph.applyTransformation(interpolator.frame());
   // draw your object here. Its position, orientation and magnitude are interpolated.
   graph.popModelView();
 }
    The key frames are defined by a frame and a time, expressed in seconds. The time has to be monotonously increasing over key frames. When speed() equals 1 (default value), these times correspond to actual user's seconds during interpolation (provided that your main loop is fast enough). The interpolation is then real-time: the key frames will be reached at their time(int).

    Interpolation details

    When start() is called, a timer is started which will update the frame()'s position, orientation and magnitude every period() milliseconds. This update increases the time() by period() * speed() milliseconds.

    Note that this mechanism ensures that the number of interpolation steps is constant and equal to the total path duration() divided by the period() * speed(). This is especially useful for benchmarking or movie creation (constant number of snapshots).

    The interpolation is stopped when time() is greater than the lastTime() (unless loop() is true). Attention: If a Constraint is attached to the frame() (see Frame.constraint()), it should be reset before start() is called, otherwise the interpolated motion (computed as if there was no constraint) will probably be erroneous.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Interpolator

        public Interpolator(Graph graph)
        Convenience constructor that simply calls this(graph, new Frame()).

        Creates an anonymous frame() to be interpolated by this interpolator.

        See Also:
        Interpolator(Frame), Interpolator(Graph, Frame)

      • Interpolator

        public Interpolator(Frame frame)
        Same as this(frame.graph(), frame). Note that frame should be attached to a Graph.
        See Also:
        Interpolator(Graph), Interpolator(Graph, Frame)

      • Interpolator

        public Interpolator(Graph graph,
                    Frame frame)
        Creates an interpolator, with frame as associated frame().

        The frame() can be set or changed using setFrame(Frame).

        time(), speed() and period() are set to their default values.

    • Method Detail

      • matches

        public boolean matches(Interpolator interpolator)
        Returns whether or not this interpolator matches other.
        Parameters:
        interpolator - other interpolator

      • get

        public Interpolator get()
        Returns a deep copy of this interpolator.

      • graph

        public Graph graph()
        Returns the graph this interpolator belongs to.

      • setFrame

        public void setFrame(Frame frame)
        Sets the interpolator frame(). If frame is instance of Frame, the frame graph (Frame.graph()) and graph() should match.

      • frame

        public Frame frame()
        Returns the frame that is to be interpolated by the interpolator.

        When started(), this frame's position, orientation and magnitude will regularly be updated by a timer, so that they follow the interpolator path.

        Set using setFrame(Frame) or with the interpolator constructor.

      • size

        public int size()
        Returns the number of key frames used by the interpolation. Use addKeyFrame(Frame) to add new key frames.

      • time

        public float time()
        Returns the current interpolation time (in seconds) along the interpolator path.

        This time is regularly updated when started(). Can be set directly with setTime(float) or interpolate(float).

      • speed

        public float speed()
        Returns the current interpolation speed.

        Default value is 1, which means time(int) will be matched during the interpolation (provided that your main loop is fast enough).

        A negative value will result in a reverse interpolation of the key frames.

        See Also:
        period()

      • period

        public int period()
        Returns the current interpolation period, expressed in milliseconds. The update of the frame() state will be done by a timer at this period when started().

        This period (multiplied by speed()) is added to the time() at each update, and the frame() state is modified accordingly (see interpolate(float)). Default value is 40 milliseconds.

        See Also:
        setPeriod(int)

      • loop

        public boolean loop()
        Returns true when the interpolation is played in an infinite loop.

        When false (default), the interpolation stops when time() reaches firstTime() (with negative speed()) or lastTime().

        time() is otherwise reset to firstTime() (+ time() - lastTime()) (and inversely for negative speed()) and interpolation continues.

      • setTime

        public void setTime(float time)
        Sets the time(). Attention: The frame() state is not affected by this method. Use this function to define the starting time of a future interpolation (see start()). Use interpolate(float) to actually interpolate at a given time.

      • setSpeed

        public void setSpeed(float speed)
        Sets the speed(). Negative or null values are allowed.

      • setPeriod

        public void setPeriod(int period)
        Sets the period(). Should positive.

      • setLoop

        public void setLoop()
        Convenience function that simply calls setLoop(true).

      • setLoop

        public void setLoop(boolean loop)
        Sets the loop() value.

      • started

        public boolean started()
        Returns true when the interpolation is being performed. Use start() or stop() to modify this state.

      • start

        public void start()
        Convenience function that simply calls start(-1).
        See Also:
        start(int)

      • start

        public void start(int period)
        Starts the interpolation process.

        A timer is started with an period() that updates the frame()'s position, orientation and magnitude. started() will return true until stop() is called.

        If period is positive, it is set as the new period(). The previous period() is used otherwise (default).

        If time() is larger than lastTime(), time() is reset to firstTime() before interpolation starts (and inversely for negative speed().

        Use setTime(float) before calling this method to change the starting time(). Attention: The key frames must be defined (see addKeyFrame(Frame, float)) before you start(), or else the interpolation will naturally immediately stop.

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stops an interpolation started with start(). See started().

      • toggle

        public void toggle()

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Stops the interpolation and resets time() to the firstTime().

        If desired, call interpolate(float) after this method to actually move the frame() to firstTime().

      • addKeyFrame

        public void addKeyFrame()
        Same as addKeyFrame(graph().eye().get()).
        See Also:
        addKeyFrame(Frame), graph(), Frame.get(), Graph.eye()

      • addKeyFrame

        public void addKeyFrame(Frame frame)
        Appends a new key frame to the path.

        Same as addKeyFrame(Frame, float), except that the time(int) is set to the previous time(int) plus one second (or 0 if there is no previous key frame).

      • addKeyFrame

        public void addKeyFrame(float time)
        Same as addKeyFrame(graph().eye().get(), time).
        See Also:
        addKeyFrame(Frame, float), graph(), Frame.get(), Graph.eye()

      • addKeyFrame

        public void addKeyFrame(Frame frame,
                        float time)
        Appends a new key frame to the path, with its associated time (in seconds).

        Note that when frame is modified, the interpolator path is updated accordingly. This allows for dynamic paths, where key frames can be edited, even during the interpolation.

        null frame references are silently ignored. The time(int) has to be monotonously increasing over key frames.

      • removeKeyFrame

        public Frame removeKeyFrame(int index)
        Remove key frame according to index in the list and stop() if started(). If index < 0 || index >= keyFr.size() the call is silently ignored.

      • purgeKeyFrame

        public void purgeKeyFrame(int index)
        Same as removeKeyFrame(int), but also removes the key frame from the scene if it is a node instance.

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Removes all key frames from the path. The size() is set to 0.
        See Also:
        purge()

      • purge

        public void purge()
        Same as clear(), but also removes the key frames node instances from the scene.
        See Also:
        clear(), Graph.pruneBranch(Frame)

      • keyFrames

        public java.util.List<Frame> keyFrames()
        Returns the list of key frames which defines this interpolator.

      • path

        public java.util.List<Frame> path()
        Computes a path from keyFrames() for the interpolator to be drawn.

        Calls _updatePath() and then returns a list of frames defining the interpolator path (which is different than that of keyFrames()).

        Use it in your interpolator path drawing routine.

      • keyFrame

        public Frame keyFrame(int index)
        Returns the frame associated with the key frame at index index.

        See also time(int). index has to be in the range 0.. size()-1.

      • time

        public float time(int index)
        Returns the time corresponding to the index key frame. Not that index has to be in the range 0.. size()-1.
        See Also:
        keyFrame(int)

      • duration

        public float duration()
        Returns the duration of the interpolator path, expressed in seconds.

        Simply corresponds to lastTime() - firstTime(). Returns 0 if the path has less than 2 key frames.

        See Also:
        time(int)

      • firstTime

        public float firstTime()
        Returns the time corresponding to the first key frame, expressed in seconds.

        Returns 0 if the path is empty.

        See Also:
        lastTime(), duration(), time(int)

      • lastTime

        public float lastTime()
        Returns the time corresponding to the last key frame, expressed in seconds.
        See Also:
        firstTime(), duration(), time(int)

      • interpolate

        public void interpolate(float time)
        Interpolate frame() at time time (expressed in seconds). time() is set to time and frame() is set accordingly.

        If you simply want to change time() but not the frame() state, use setTime(float) instead.
